text:
You then get hired to run the Nigerian
Sovereign Investment Authority (NSIA).
This is a brand new agency.

There is a picture of what
it should be doing within the country, but
it really doesn't exist.
And so here you are at ground zero.
It was quite interesting how,

for all the fanfare of setting up
the organization, it still came down

to being a truly entrepreneurial venture
from scratch.

And an entrepreneurial venture
within the government.
Within the government.
Which is doubly difficult.
Which is doubly difficult

because the government didn't
transfer the capital for management for...

It was all kinds of complexity between
the Central Bank and the new agency...

There were all kinds
of government processes

they need to get- We took nine months
before we got the capital.
So, in between, I rented this place.

I lived upstairs and put the Sovereign
Wealth Fund on the ground floor.

We started looking to put together
a business plan.

We had called McKinsey to help us
write it, but McKinsey
quoted an astronomical amount of money.

I said, "Okay,
now I will write it myself."

So I did write the business plan
for the organization,

and I remember how difficult it was
to even get service providers.
We could not get an investment adviser.
We put out a bid.
No one turned up.

I went to New York to see my family,
and it turns out that somebody

who had been a good client of mine had now
become a senior at Cambridge Associate.

I assured him that
this was not a fake venture.
This is real and I am the CEO.

So eventually, getting people hired,
we had no money
because we were self-funding ourselves.
I went to the British government.

We've got five people from the Department
for International Development

(DFID) to help us get started and that's
how we started building the organization.

There were two wonderful
outcomes from that.
Number one,

because we are all self-funding,
we learned to be very, very careful -

and somebody would say "stingy" -
with the resources.

The second thing was we ended up working
together excellently well as a team.

Because we were all working up
on the same dining table - right?
- which was the office.

I think the third was we earned
the respect of the Minister of Finance.

I remember She said to me, "So,
how have you been operating?
You haven't received the money.
You haven't said anything!"

I said, "Well, I did write a letter,
but somehow-" She said, "No, no, no, no,

but how have you been coping?" I said,
"Well, we've just got along with it."
She goes, "How?

You mean
you've been putting out all of this
and you are the ones self-funding it?"

I go, "Well,
you don't complain about such things.
I have faith it will come eventually.

But you know, let's not worry
too much about such mundane matters.
We can sort it out ourselves."

So learning to be self-sufficient
for us was very, very important

because that's served us well subsequently
as we dealt with government.
